I've used Thunderbird for years with no problems. Any help would be great! Thanks, Dave

title: Setting up a new domain with personal email and forwarding to my ISP
content: For 20 years I have used the dot name domain and it integral email forwarding and email format. However, the increased scam protection by gmail has led to all my mail addressed to gmail a/c fails the authentication process. Hence, I need to buy a new domain, not for web hosting, just email, that I own the full rights to setup and manage, ie, beyond the constraints built into dot name. GoDaddy can provide a suitable domain, but also insist I'll also have to include MS 365 Email Essentials. I suspect the latter uses MS Exchange but I'm not an IT guru. So am looking for the tools to maybe DIY setting up an email based on name@newdomain.au with the appropriate authentication and email forwarding to my ISP. Is Thunderbird that tool, or are their better alternatives? All help and advice is welcome.
creator: longinthetooth

title: Thunderbird centers email list on selected email
content:
Thunderbird's previous behavior: When clicking on an email to read, the email displays in the reading pane - but the list of emails does not change position. When I want to scroll up or down, I do it manually.

Thunderbird's new behavior upon upgrading to the latest client: When clicking on an email to read, the list of emails automatically centers on the email clicked. I'm having to constantly scroll back up or down to reset the view to how I had it.

The new behavior is extremely irritating and causes a lot of extra scrolling - if I wanted it to show that view, I'd center it there myself! Is there a way to turn off the autofocusing? I looked in the configuration settings but everything I tried didn't seem to have an effect on that behavior.

title: PWS:HTML/Phish.QA malware
content:
Hi Thunderbird has been my go to app for email for years but in the last few years I find that in windows, it triggers MS defender quarantining PWS:HTML/Phish.QA. Apparently it tries to capture passwords. It seems to pop up a couple of times one after the other and then again maybe each hour or so. Microsoft help people when I asked them about this a year or two ago said just tag it for the anti virus software to ignore it. I was uneasy about that advice. I have solved it in the past by installing separate anti virus packages which seem to ignore it, but I would rather not deal with all that if possible. The offending file seems to be in a sent email folder in an imap folder so it comes up each time I do a new install on a windows machine.

Could someone point me in the right direction? Is it a matter of finding and deleting something in a sent mail folder? Probably more complicated than that . . .

Cheers, Ken
creator: kgw319

title: Who want to join me in an accessibility law suit against Mozilla and Thunderbird? The latest version of TBird is unusable.
content:
Who wants to join me in an accessibility law suit against Mozilla and Thunderbird? The latest version of TBird is unusable.

Put the Menu bar back at the top. Allow us to globally turn off 'sort treads into conversations' and make it the default. This is not a texting app. Stop forcing changes on us. We don't want them.

Fix the tool bar and Search Bar so it works like it did for the previous decade.

Do the developers track crap from the sidewalk into their offices by Fisherman's Warf so they think crap is the new form of coding. Just code Thunderbird into a pile of crap.

Mozilla et al only gives lip service to accessibility.

content:
Hi there, I have a number of folders in Thunderbird for archiving emails, each with the name of the sender. Today I noticed, that in some of them quite a number of emails have lost their dates, sender, recipient, subject, and are now showing a time from today only. This was initially the time when I started thunderbird this afternoon, but when I delete the ".thunderbird" folder (Linux Mint) and use a backed up folder, it will show the time of when I then restarted Thunderbird. I tried several backups going back to early this year- all the same result. Some emails seem to be missing entirely in one of pop- IN folders starting from 11/12/23 till today. I use POP to get my emails, with no backup on the mailserver of my provider. I attach a screenshot of one archived folder. The shown folder should contain 1070 emails.

Do you have any ideas what might have happened, and what I could do to get the proper dates back in place, and be sure no emails have been lost? Many thanks in advance

title: "2FA" vs "Open PGP key" vs "S-MIME certificat"
content:
Hello,

I want to install a lock on my mailbox. I thought two factor authentication is the best way to do so. However, I do not see any info about 2fa and Thunderbird. What I do see is: info about Open PGP key and S-MIME certificats to encrypt messages. I think both adds to security, however, it appears to me that the 2fa is the real lock and encrypting messages is useful in case the lock hasn't worked well: the messages can be read by a third person, but not understood. Is that right? And do I understand it correctly that there's no 2FA option for thunderbird? Is encrypting messages as safe and convenient as 2FA?

Hopefully someone could help me out...I'm a non-techie as you might already assume;), hopefully this can be taken into account..

Thanks! Simone

title: Issues receiving e-mails
content:
Good afternoon, from time to time we have had issues receiving e-mails on both our desktops with Ubuntu 22.04 since we upgraded to Thunderbird 115.5.0. It mostly happens after booting the machines in the morning, but sometimes it also occurs spontaneously during the day. Internet works well, so does sending e-mails. Shutting down and booting again will help sometimes, but I also have to restart the router upstairs (Netgear) again from time to time. I checked all settings, closed Surfshark VPN, contacted our provider that checked the connections up to their modem / router in our home, everything was fine. I then installed another router (ASUS RT-AC87U) that gave the same problem. Also installed a timer that switches on half an hour before booting both computers so that we do not have to switch it off manually and we are sure the router already had a reset. Another issue on both computers: when some times we cannot receive e-mails and we reset router or computers, some e-mails that had been deleted reappear in the Inbox as if we had not opened them...... You might imagine that I am at the end of my possibilities to find a solution. Would you please help me? Kind regards, Ed

PS. I had already signed into my Mozilla account and had sent the same message.....

title: Thunderbird deleted emails from the server when compacting
content: I just installed version 115.6.0. My email is set up as IMAP. All settings are such that no email ever should get deleted from the server. There are plenty of files in "AppData\Roaming\..........\INBOX.sbd\Archive.sdb", so I suspect that's where the emails were moved to, but this archive does not show up anywhere in Thunderbird. How can I stop Thunderbird deleting the emails, and how do I restore the emails from the archive to the IMAP server?

title: Unable to access my Gmail accounts
content: Since 'upgrading' to the Supernova version, I have multiplying problems. I have 3 gmail accounts, all of which I used to be able to access through Tbird. Nice and easy! I use POP, not IMAP. Very soon after loading one of the 115 versions, I lost access to one of my accounts. That was some weeks ago now. I tried deleting the account from Tbird and then re-adding it. I got an error message from Google. I have tried it MANY times with the same result, and so can no longer access it via Tbird. I have needed to access direct online via Chrome and Gmail and copy to one of my other gmail accounts which Tbird DOES read OK. Now a second account is experiencing the same problem. I have not deleted it from Tbird, as I don't want the same fiasco again. BUT, every few minutes, as Tbird checks my emails, I get a login window which I complete – which produces the same Google error message. This means that Tbird no longer accesses THAT email account, either. I now have only one Gmail account that Tbird can access, and I am concerned that that one may also fail. I SHOULD PREFER TO REVERT TO THE TBIRD VERSION WHICH IMMEDIATELY PRECEDED THE FIRST 'SUPERNOVA'. As far as I can see, Supernova is a disaster. There are other minor frustrations with it, which were not there before. I have a LOT of information stored in many folders and sub-folders, which previous Tbird versions handled well. Supernova is still OK with them, but I want to be sure to preserve all that information if I need to delete Tbird in order to revert to an earlier (and therefore reliable!) version.
creator: blackberrylane.co.uk
